data.text:
Health Check notes:

Need to decide on the income/monetary interoperability.

Suggested approach is:

Choose a date study was conducted on, convert to dollars on that date, then adjust for inflation to 1 January 2015 for interoperability.

heart_attack: This is a history of MI, not current MI, the codebook I think is best used for current MI.

stroke: This is a history of stroke, not current stroke, the codebook I think is best used for current stroke.

Note: don’t map two variables from the source to one variable in the codebook unless dates are different.

Dates can only ever map to dates

The lab values don’t have an explicit date, which is unfortunate, but based on the protocol, I would guess all of the tests were done on the same day and we can probably presume that corresponds to gsk\_seendate.  They also didn’t include a lot of variables, like cd4, in the dataset, which I think would be worthwhile getting from them. I have presumed demographics were taken on gsk\_date.

No units in codebook, but presuming based on values and standard SA units.

We don’t have pregnancy in codebook, but not sure if there is enough interesting pregnancy data to warrant the inclusion in the codebook.

?add glucose to codebook

data.text:
Hi Ty and Jennifer

‌

Can you please assist us here? The publication says

‌

The study protocol was reviewed and approved by the University of California at San Francisco Institutional Review Board Committee on Human Research, and by the ethics review committees at all local institutions and collaborating organisations, including the Medical Research Council of Zimbabwe, the Medicines Control Authority of Zimbabwe, Biomedical Research Ethics Committee of the University of KwaZulu-Natal, Human Research Ethics Committee of the University of the Witwatersrand, and Western Institutional Review Board. An independent external audit, sponsored by Ibis Reproductive Health, was done by the Quintiles Corporation in November 2005, after study accrual was completed.

‌

Can you please check so we can proceed with our analysis? If you cannot find it, I can go back to RTI and ask them to send it from their side.

‌

Craig

data.text:
Dear Dr Chersich,
The study requested is not sponsored by Roche, but by a different company. As there is a partnership between these companies we asked the sponsor for permission to share the requested study (CAPSTONE-2) for your planned analysis. The did not approve the sharing because they do not think there is enough rationale to share this study for the research you want to do.

Additionally, as we mentioned before, the essential data which is required for your analysis has either not been collected in the study or cannot be shared for privacy reasons and would therefore be removed during anonymisation.

Best regards,
Roche Data Sharing Team

data.text:
For

‌

Item

Matthew, Gueladio, Christopher and Craig

Attached please find the HVTN’s Agreement on Confidentiality and Use of Data and Specimens for Auxiliary Studies. **Please read it and reply to **[**vtn.core.reg@hvtn.org**](mailto:vtn.core.reg@hvtn.org "‌")** that you agree to comply with it.**

Sibusisiwe

It appears that the institution with which you are affiliated is a for-profit entity and therefore the HVTN's institution, Fred Hutch Cancer Center, requires a Data Transfer Agreement (DTA) be put in place with you before the data can be shared for this study. One of my colleagues who works on legal agreements will contact you separately about this.

‌

‌

**Notification**

For

Item

Everyone

Please read the attached HVTN Publication Policy. You are required to follow this policy and we will assist you in complying with it.  Please refer to the Policy for standard review timelines and send copies of manuscripts, abstracts, posters, or presentations for review and comment to:

‌

1. **MATFLU (Influenza Vaccine Trials in Pregnant Women) (RP1 only)**

- **MATFLU-HIVneg**: Influenza Vaccine Trial in HIV-Uninfected Pregnant Women. [Study Information](https://academic.oup.com/jpids/article/4/1/78/920785 "‌").
- **MATFLU-HIVpos**: Influenza Vaccine Trial in HIV-Infected Pregnant Women. [Study Information](https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/65/7/1066/3858145 "‌").

‌

1. **SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine Trials in South African Adults (JHB\_VIDA\_007_ChadOx1) I can only find one card on this. Ethics has approved**

- **Adaptive Phase 1/II Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial**: [Study Information](https://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2020-06-23-trial-oxford-covid-19-vaccine-south-africa-begins "‌")

‌

1. **Health Worker COVID-19 Study at CHBH (JHB\_VIDA\_008 PMC). Ethics has approved.**

- This study focuses on COVID-19's impact among health workers at Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital (CHBH).

‌

1. **Pfizer GBS Studies: 28OB, GBS-COP (Pfizer GBS studies: 28OB, GBS-COP (possible) : VIDA). Not yet approeved, it would be good to understand if Alane was open to sharing this in your discussion.**

- **28OB Study**: [Study Information](https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/fda-grants-breakthrough-therapy-designation-pfizers-group-b "‌").
- **GBS-COP Study**: [Study Information](https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/pfizer-begins-phase-1-clinical-trial-evaluate-investigational "‌").

data.text: @pierrelouiskloppers Study setting The proposed project will be built onto the current community-based HCT (mobile and fixed) services offered by Aurum. We plan to include six HCT teams, 3 operating in Ekurhuleni District (Gauteng Province) and 3 in Limpopo. The HCT units serve peri-urban townships and informal settlements, rural farm workers, and both urban and rural communities. I am still trying to work out how they differentiate between the HCT team in Ekurhuleni versus Limpopo in the their codebook.

data.text:
Dear Dr Chersich,
The study requested is not sponsored by Roche, but by a different company. As there is a partnership between these companies we asked the sponsor for permission to share the requested study (CAPSTONE-2) for your planned analysis. The did not approve the sharing because they do not think there is enough rationale to share this study for the research you want to do.

Additionally, as we mentioned before, the essential data which is required for your analysis has either not been collected in the study or cannot be shared for privacy reasons and would therefore be removed during anonymisation.

Best regards,
Roche Data Sharing Team

data.text:
Dear Dr. Chersich and Research Team,

we are sharing anonymized data of the ORIGIN study to protect the privacy of participants. For example, dates are shifted and therefore not real, and it may be difficult to link with temperature. Geographical location/country may be grouped and SITEID is regenerated data. Therefore, data specific to the town of Johannesburg are not provided. We recommend reviewing our updated anonymization standards available on our member page for details how data are prepared for sharing.

Best regards,
Sanofi Data Sharing Team

data.text:
@elizabethfrederick14 sorry Elizabeth, UCT is not happy to proceed with transferring the data for this study.

1. The DTA was signed by the PI/PhD student rather than the legal representative of his university. We have PhD studies included in RP1 and these were signed by the University legal department.
2. I can’t find the ethics approval
3. I can’t find the consent form
4. I can’t find the study protocol

All of these documents should have been provided and reviewed before the DTA process commenced since they are needed to confirm if this study is eligible and meets out requirements.

data.text:
Dear Boehringer Ingelheim Data Sharing Team,

Thank you for your update regarding the availability of the study team for the trial NCT00144183. We understand the challenges due to the study’s age and the current status of the team. We appreciate your efforts in processing our request and are willing to accommodate any additional time required to facilitate access to the data. This study is crucial for our research, and we are grateful for your continued support.

Best regards,
Craig Parker
On behalf of Dr. Chersich and the HE²AT Center Team

list.name: Expressed interest in participating/Next steps email or address queries on application

data.text:
Dear Dr. Antoni and the Sanofi Data Sharing Team,

Thank you for your follow-up.

The inclusion of the ORIGIN study data is critical to our project for several reasons:

1. **Cardiovascular Focus**: The ORIGIN trial's emphasis on cardiovascular outcomes in individuals with dysglycemia (including impaired fasting glucose, impaired glucose tolerance, and early type 2 diabetes) aligns with our project's goal of understanding the intersection between cardiovascular health, diabetes, and heat exposure, particularly in vulnerable populations.
2. **Diabetes and Heat Vulnerability**: Diabetes, particularly in its early stages, can significantly alter an individual's physiological response to environmental stressors like heat. The detailed metabolic and cardiovascular data collected in the ORIGIN study would allow us to examine how pre-existing dysglycemia impacts the body's response to heat exposure.
3. **Relevance to Johannesburg**: We are working closely with PI Aysha Badat at the WCR Bara Clinical Trial Centre in Johannesburg. The ORIGIN data, particularly from participants in urban settings like Johannesburg, will enable us to perform localized analyses, making our findings more applicable and actionable for urban public health planning in similar settings.

This data will be instrumental in refining our models and ultimately developing early warning systems that consider the compounded risks faced by people with metabolic disorders in urban environments.

We hope this clarifies the importance of the ORIGIN study data for our research.

Best regards,
Craig Parker
On behalf of Dr. Chersich and the Research Team

old.desc:
Combination Therapies to Reduce Carriage of SARS-Cov-2 and Improve Outcome of COVID-19 in Ivory Coast: a Phase Randomized IIb Trial

NCT04466241

PI : Serge Eholié

Number of participants: 294

Study date: 2020-2021

Study Start (Actual)

2020-11-27

Primary Completion (Estimated)

2021-03-26

Study Completion (Estimated)

2021-03-26

Enrollment (Estimated)

294

These drugs include the LPV/r already in use in Côte d'Ivoire as well as an antihypertensive drug - telmisartan, and a drug that lowers blood cholesterol - atorvastatin. All three have been known for a long time and have been shown to be effective against other viruses. In addition, they are generic, inexpensive and readily available in all countries.

The objectives of the ICOV study are therefore to improve viral eradication from the patient's body and respiratory tract, to reduce inflammation, to improve more rapidly the patient's state of health and to reduce the risk of transmission of the virus to others.

To participate in ICOV, patients must be over 18 years of age, have a COVID-19 infection confirmed by a specific test, have clinical manifestations of the infection, and have signed an informed consent. They will then be randomized into 3 treatment groups to ensure the robustness of the study results. The reference group will be treated with LPV/r, according to current recommendations in Côte d'Ivoire. The other 2 groups will be treated with LPV/r + telmisartan and LPV/r + atorvastatin respectively. The treatment will last 10 days and patients will be followed for a total of 28 days

card.desc:
Recommendation Arianna van Straaten -access to this study.

### Summary of the TRIO Study

#### Title:

The Tablets, Ring, Injections as Options (TRIO) study: what young African women chose and used for future HIV and pregnancy prevention.

#### Authors:

Ariane van der Straten, Kawango Agot, Khatija Ahmed, Rachel Weinrib, Erica N Browne, Kgahlisho Manenzhe, Fredrick Owino, Jill Schwartz, and Alexandra Minnis on behalf of the TRIO Study Team.

#### Introduction:

The TRIO study aimed to evaluate the preference and use of three placebo delivery forms (daily oral tablets, monthly vaginal rings, and two-monthly intramuscular injections) for HIV and pregnancy prevention among young African women in Kenya and South Africa. This study addresses global health priorities by exploring multipurpose prevention technologies (MPTs).

#### Methods:

- Participants: HIV-negative, sexually active, non-pregnant women aged 18-30.
- Study Design: Five-month study with two stages.
  - Stage 1: Each participant used each placebo delivery form for one month.
  - Stage 2: Participants chose one product to use for two additional months.
- Evaluation: Safety, product ranking, choice, and use were assessed. Demographic and behavioral correlates of choice and unwillingness to use were analyzed using logistic regression models.

#### Results:

- **Participants**: 277 women enrolled, 249 completed stage 1, and 246 completed stage 2.
- **Adverse Events**: 18 product-related adverse events (6 tablets, 11 rings, 1 injection).
- **Preference**: 85% preferred a TRIO product over condoms. Injections were most preferred (64%), followed by tablets (21%) and rings (15%).
- **Adherence**: Improved adherence over time for tablets and rings; participants were fully compliant with injections.
- **Demographic Correlates**: South African women were more likely to choose injections, while Kenyan women preferred tablets. No significant difference in ring choice by country.

#### Conclusion:

All participants agreed to use a placebo MPT form. Injections were the most preferred and best-used product. While injections are not yet clinic-ready, expanding access to tablets and rings can provide more options for HIV prevention.

#### Keywords:

Multipurpose prevention technologies, end-user research, HIV prevention, product preference, contraception, Africa.

For more details and specific data points, you can refer to the full study [here](https://doi.org/10.1002/jia2.25094 "‌").

data.text:
Hi Matthew and Darsh, 

To proceed with the secondary analysis of the HOPE, VOICE, and ASPIRE studies, we need to **draft and sign Data Transfer Agreements (DTAs)**. Additionally, we require the following documents for each study:

1. **Study Protocol**
2. **Informed Consent Forms**
3. **Wits Ethics Certification Number** (original and latest)

Here is what we require in terms of documentation for each of these studies along with the DTA:

1. **HOPE (MTN-025)**
   - Signed DTA
   - Study Protocol
   - Informed Consent Forms
   - Wits Ethics Certification Number
2. **VOICE (MTN-003)**
   - Signed DTA
   - Wits Ethics Certification Number
3. **ASPIRE (MTN-020)**
   - Signed DTA
   - Wits Ethics Certification Number

It is also important to make sure we get the lowest level of geo-location data possible for each study

Thanks, 

Craig

card.desc:
Combination Therapies to Reduce Carriage of SARS-Cov-2 and Improve Outcome of COVID-19 in Ivory Coast: a Phase Randomized IIb Trial

NCT04466241

PI : Serge Eholié

Number of participants: 294

Study date: 2020-2021

Study Start (Actual)

2020-11-27

Primary Completion (Estimated)

2021-03-26

Study Completion (Estimated)

2021-03-26

Enrollment (Estimated)

294

These drugs include the LPV/r already in use in Côte d'Ivoire as well as an antihypertensive drug - telmisartan, and a drug that lowers blood cholesterol - atorvastatin. All three have been known for a long time and have been shown to be effective against other viruses. In addition, they are generic, inexpensive and readily available in all countries.

The objectives of the ICOV study are therefore to improve viral eradication from the patient's body and respiratory tract, to reduce inflammation, to improve more rapidly the patient's state of health and to reduce the risk of transmission of the virus to others.

To participate in ICOV, patients must be over 18 years of age, have a COVID-19 infection confirmed by a specific test, have clinical manifestations of the infection, and have signed an informed consent. They will then be randomized into 3 treatment groups to ensure the robustness of the study results. The reference group will be treated with LPV/r, according to current recommendations in Côte d'Ivoire. The other 2 groups will be treated with LPV/r + telmisartan and LPV/r + atorvastatin respectively. The treatment will last 10 days and patients will be followed for a total of 28 days

cards.desc:
The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a single, oral dose of baloxavir marboxil compared with placebo by measuring the time to improvement of influenza symptoms in patients with influenza presenting within 48 hours of symptom onset. The study was conducted between January 11, 2017 and April 20, 2018 and was sponsored by Shionogi Inc.

The study record identifier (NCT number) for this study is **NCT02949011**. The study sponsor is **Shionogi Inc.** and the Principal Investigator (PI) is not mentioned in the study record. The actual enrollment for this study was **2184 participants**.

there were 8 study sites in South Africa that participated in the CAPSTONE 2 trial:

Shionogi Research Site Boksburg, Gauteng, South Africa
Shionogi Research Site Johannesburg, Gauteng, South Africa
Shionogi Research Site Pretoria, Gauteng, South Africa
Shionogi Research Site Randburg, Gauteng, South Africa
Shionogi Research Site Tembisa, Gauteng, South Africa
Shionogi Research Site Durban, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa
Shionogi Research Site Thabazimbi, Limpopo, South Africa
Shionogi Research Site Welkom, Free State, South Africa

According to the clinical trial results published in The Lancet, a total of 278 patients were enrolled in the CAPSTONE 2 trial from South African sites. This represents 6.9% of the total 4,023 participants in the trial.

Aysha Badat

NCT00864383

Study Type :Interventional  (Clinical Trial)Actual Enrollment :1931

Number of Locations: 47 Locations

Clinical HIV Research Unit (CHRU)Johannesburg, Westdene, **South Africa**, 2092

Study Title: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind Trial Comparing Different Drug Combinations for Treating Adult Pulmonary Tuberculosis

Study Design: Participants are randomly assigned to different treatment groups in a parallel manner. The study is quadruple-masked, meaning that the participant, care provider, investigator, and outcome assessor are all unaware of the treatment group assignments. The main goal of the study is to compare the effectiveness of different treatment regimens.

Treatment Comparison:

A two-month intensive phase comparing a combination of Ethambutol, Moxifloxacin, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide to the standard regimen (Ethambutol, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide).

A treatment shortening regimen comparing two months of Moxifloxacin, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide followed by two months of Moxifloxacin, Isoniazid, and Rifampicin to the standard regimen (two months of Ethambutol, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide followed by four months of Isoniazid and Rifampicin).

Important Dates:

Study started in January 2008
Primary completion in October 2013
Study completed in February 2014

This trial compares how safe and effective 26 weeks of Delamanid (DLM) is versus 26 weeks of isoniazid (INH) for preventing infection with TB or confirmed or probable active infection with TB among high-risk household contacts (HHC). High-risk household contacts are those with HIV or an immune system problem not from HIV like cancer, latent TB infection, and young children below the age of 5 years. The study will last for 96 weeks and all participants will be randomly assigned one of two groups: DLM daily for adults, adolescents, and children, given for 26 weeks; INH daily for adults, adolescents, and children, given for 26 weeks; Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) daily for adults, adolescents, and children, given for 26 weeks.

HVTN 705/HPX2008 – Soweto-Bara Clinical Research Site	 Fatima Laher		NCT03060629	HVTN 705/HPX2008

Trial title: A Study to Assess the Efficacy of a Heterologous Prime/Boost Vaccine Regimen of Ad26.Mos4.HIV and Aluminum Phosphate-Adjuvanted Clade C gp140 in Preventing Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) -1 Infection in Women in Sub-Saharan Africa
Study status: Completed
Study type: Phase 2b, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled
Study objective: To assess the preventive vaccine efficacy (VE) of a heterologous prime/boost vaccine regimen of Ad26.Mos4.HIV and aluminum phosphate-adjuvanted Clade C gp140 in preventing HIV-1 infection in HIV-seronegative women residing in sub-Saharan Africa.
Study population: HIV-seronegative women aged 18 to 45 years who were at high risk of HIV infection.
Interventions: Participants were randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments:
Vaccine regimen: Ad26.Mos4.HIV at Months 0 and 2, followed by aluminum phosphate-adjuvanted Clade C gp140 at Month 4
Placebo
Primary outcome: VE of the vaccine regimen against HIV-1 infection
Secondary outcomes:
Safety
Immunogenicity
The trial was conducted in 11 countries in sub-Saharan Africa and enrolled over 2,600 participants. The results of the trial showed that the vaccine regimen did not meet its primary endpoint of preventing HIV-1 infection. However, the vaccine regimen was found to be safe and well-tolerated.

The full results of the trial were published in the journal The Lancet in 2021. The study was funded by Janssen Vaccines & Prevention B.V., part of the Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson.

The Soweto-Bara Clinical Research Site was one of the 11 study sites in sub-Saharan Africa that participated in the HVTN 705/HPX2008 trial. The site was located in Soweto, South Africa, and was led by Dr. Fatima Laher. The site enrolled a total of 200 participants in the trial.

cards.desc:
Added as a new study based on the discussions with Ariane:

[https://www.mtnstopshiv.org/news/mtn-020-aspire](https://www.mtnstopshiv.org/news/mtn-020-aspire "smartCard-inline")

he MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial was a Phase 3, multi-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the dapivirine vaginal ring (VR) for the prevention of HIV-1 infection in healthy, sexually active, HIV-negative women. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of a dapivirine (25 mg) silicone elastomer matrix VR, inserted once every 4 weeks, in preventing HIV-1 infection and to assess its safety compared to a placebo VR.

A total of 2,629 participants were enrolled and randomized to receive either the dapivirine VR or a placebo VR. Participants used the VRs until 120 HIV-1 seroconversions were observed, with a minimum expected use of 12 months. The trial completed follow-up on June 25, 2015, and primary results were presented in February 2016, with the primary manuscript published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

**Primary Results**

The trial demonstrated that the monthly dapivirine VR was safe and effective for HIV prevention. There were no significant differences in primary safety endpoints between the study arms, and sexually transmitted infections occurred at similar rates. A total of 168 incident HIV-1 infections occurred during the product use period, with a 27% relative reduction in HIV-1 acquisition in the dapivirine ring arm compared to the placebo arm.

Subgroup analyses showed that HIV-1 protection differed significantly by age, with women ≥25 years of age demonstrating 61% protection, while those <25 years of age had no statistically significant reduction in HIV-1 incidence. Further analyses indicated that lack of HIV-1 protection and lower adherence were limited to participants ≤21 years of age.

**Study Details**

- **Protocol Chair(s):** Jared Baeten (Protocol Chair), Thesla Palanee-Phillips (Protocol Co-Chair)
- **Protocol Title:** A Multi-Center, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Phase 3 Safety and Effectiveness Trial of a Vaginal Matrix Ring Containing Dapivirine for the Prevention of HIV-1 Infection in Women
- **DAIDS Protocol ID:** 11840
- **Status:** Participants off Study and Primary Analysis Completed
- **Formulation:** Vaginal Ring
- **Drug:** Dapivirine, Placebo
- **Study Focus/Product Administration:** Vaginal
- **Study Type:** Behavioral, Efficacy, Safety
- **Study Phase:** Phase III
- **Countries:** Malawi, South Africa, Uganda, Zimbabwe
- **Population:** Women (cisgender women, non‐transgender women)
- **Funder(s):** Division of AIDS, US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, US National Institutes of Health
- **Sponsor(s):** IPM
- **Other Study Info:** Phase 3, multi-site, two-arm, randomized (1:1), double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

This summary provides an overview of the MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial, focusing on its objectives, primary results, and key details.

cards.desc:
Study title: A Phase III, Multi-Centre, Randomised Controlled Trial to Assess the Safety and Effectiveness of the Vaginal Microbicide 1% Tenofovir Gel in the Prevention of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Type 1 Infection in  Young Women, and to Examine Effects of the Microbicide on the Incidence of Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 Infection (FACTS)

N=2200

‌

Manuscript/Presentation Concept Proposal for the HEAT Center Send to Sinead 11/28

The FACTS 001 was launched in October 2011, and will enrol a minimum of 2,200 HIV-uninfected women aged 18-30 at nine clinical trial sites across South Africa.

The FACTS 001 study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of a vaginal microbicide gel containing 1% tenofovir in preventing HIV-1 acquisition in women. The study was conducted between 2005 and 2010 in South Africa. The study found that the tenofovir gel reduced HIV-1 acquisition by 39% overall and by 54% in women with high adherence. The study concluded that the tenofovir gel could be an effective method for preventing HIV-1 acquisition in women.

[FACTS 001 Study | FACTS Consortium (wordpress.com)](https://factsconsortium.wordpress.com/facts-001-study/#:~:text=The%20FACTS%20001%20study%20is%20a%20phase%20III%2C,virus%20%28HSV-2%29%2C%20the%20virus%20that%20causes%20genital%20herpes. "‌")

NCT01386294

[Safety and Effectiveness of Tenofovir Gel in the Prevention of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV-1) Infection in Women and the Effects of Tenofovir Gel on the Incidence of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-2) Infection - Full Text View - ClinicalTrials.gov](https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01386294?term=FACTS001&draw=2&rank=2 "‌")

The study will evaluate several secondary endpoints that bear directly on potential risks and benefits of vaginal tenofovir gel use. These include incidence of HIV-1 infection, incidence of pregnancy loss, prematurity, low birth weight, and major and minor congenital anomalies. All women will be evaluated for the rates of adverse events and the rate of HIV seroconversion

cards.desc:
Recommendation Arianna van Straaten -access to this study.

### Summary of the TRIO Study

#### Title:

The Tablets, Ring, Injections as Options (TRIO) study: what young African women chose and used for future HIV and pregnancy prevention.

#### Authors:

Ariane van der Straten, Kawango Agot, Khatija Ahmed, Rachel Weinrib, Erica N Browne, Kgahlisho Manenzhe, Fredrick Owino, Jill Schwartz, and Alexandra Minnis on behalf of the TRIO Study Team.

#### Introduction:

The TRIO study aimed to evaluate the preference and use of three placebo delivery forms (daily oral tablets, monthly vaginal rings, and two-monthly intramuscular injections) for HIV and pregnancy prevention among young African women in Kenya and South Africa. This study addresses global health priorities by exploring multipurpose prevention technologies (MPTs).

#### Methods:

- Participants: HIV-negative, sexually active, non-pregnant women aged 18-30.
- Study Design: Five-month study with two stages.
  - Stage 1: Each participant used each placebo delivery form for one month.
  - Stage 2: Participants chose one product to use for two additional months.
- Evaluation: Safety, product ranking, choice, and use were assessed. Demographic and behavioral correlates of choice and unwillingness to use were analyzed using logistic regression models.

#### Results:

- **Participants**: 277 women enrolled, 249 completed stage 1, and 246 completed stage 2.
- **Adverse Events**: 18 product-related adverse events (6 tablets, 11 rings, 1 injection).
- **Preference**: 85% preferred a TRIO product over condoms. Injections were most preferred (64%), followed by tablets (21%) and rings (15%).
- **Adherence**: Improved adherence over time for tablets and rings; participants were fully compliant with injections.
- **Demographic Correlates**: South African women were more likely to choose injections, while Kenyan women preferred tablets. No significant difference in ring choice by country.

#### Conclusion:

All participants agreed to use a placebo MPT form. Injections were the most preferred and best-used product. While injections are not yet clinic-ready, expanding access to tablets and rings can provide more options for HIV prevention.

#### Keywords:

Multipurpose prevention technologies, end-user research, HIV prevention, product preference, contraception, Africa.

For more details and specific data points, you can refer to the full study [here](https://doi.org/10.1002/jia2.25094 "‌").

cards.desc:
Pfizer has conducted multiple studies related to Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), including the 28OB and GBS-COP VIDA studies.

The 28OB study was a phase III, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a candidate vaccine for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) in pregnant women. GBS is a common bacterium that can cause serious infections in newborns, including sepsis and meningitis. The study included over 3,600 pregnant women from 18 countries, and found that the vaccine was effective in preventing GBS infection in infants.

The GBS-COP VIDA study was a retrospective cohort study that evaluated the risk of GBS following vaccination with the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine. The study analyzed data from over 100 million vaccinated individuals in the United States, and found that the risk of GBS following vaccination with the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine was very low, with an estimated 1-2 cases per million vaccinated individuals. The study concluded that the benefits of vaccination against COVID-19 far outweigh the risks of GBS

28OB took place in Wits Reproductive Health and HIV InstituteJohannesburg, Gauteng, South Africa, 2001Respiratory and Meningeal Pathogens Research Unit (RMPRU)Soweto, Gauteng, South Africa, 1862Empilweni Services and Research Unit (ESRU)Coronationville, Johannesburg, South Africa, 2093Charlotte Maxeke Johannesburg Academic HospitalParktown, Johannesburg, South Africa, 2196

Title: Multicenter Adaptive SOLIDARITY - COVID-19 Clinical Trial

PI: Mohammed Siddique Rassool [mrassool@witshealth.co.za](mailto:mrassool@witshealth.co.za "‌")

The main hypothesis of the study is not explicitly stated in the abstract or the article. However, the study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of four repurposed antiviral drugs in large, randomized trials for hospitalized patients with Covid-19¹.

Source: Conversation with Bing, 2023/04/24(1) [https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184.](https://xn--www-820q.nejm.xn--org-g30q/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184. "‌") [https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184](https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184 "‌")  Accessed 2023/04/24.

The primary analyses examined in-hospital mortality in the four pairwise comparisons of each trial drug and its control (drug available but patient assigned to the same care without that drug). The rate ratios for death were calculated with stratification according to age and status regarding mechanical ventilation at trial entry¹.

Source: Conversation with Bing, 2023/04/24(1) [https://www.who.int/.../solidarity-clinical-trial-for-covid-19-treatments/interim-results.](https://xn--www-820q.who.xn--int-g30q/.../%EE%80%80solidarity%EE%80%81-clinical-%EE%80%80trial%EE%80%81-for-covid-19-treatments/%EE%80%80interim-results%EE%80%81. "‌") [https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/global-research-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov/solidarity-clinical-trial-for-covid-19-treatments/interim-results](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/global-research-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov/solidarity-clinical-trial-for-covid-19-treatments/interim-results "‌")  Accessed 2023/04/24.

Patients included in the present analysis are from 30 countries from the six WHO Regions: Albania; Argentina; Austria; Belgium; Brazil; Canada; Colombia; Egypt; Finland; France; Honduras; India; Indonesia; Iran; Ireland; Italy; Kuwait; Lebanon; Lithuania; Luxembourg; Malaysia; North Macedonia; Norway; Pakistan; Peru; Philippines; Saudi Arabia; South Africa; Spain; and Switzerland

VOICE is designed as a five-arm, double-blinded study in which women are first randomized to receive either gel or oral PrEP, and then within each group, randomly assigned to either tenofovir topical gel or placebo gel; or to oral tenofovir, oral Truvada or oral placebo. The study will enroll approximately 5,000 women at 15 sites in South Africa, Zimbabwe, and Uganda.

cards.desc:
Here are the main points of the study:

- The study aims to characterise the key transmissibility and clinical features of, and the antibody response to, SARS-CoV-2 in South Africa.
- The study also aims to enhance surveillance for COVID-19, identify groups at increased risk of severe illness, estimate the disease burden of medically- and non-medically attended mild, severe-non-fatal and fatal illness, and forecast the impact of the outbreak on the healthcare system and society in South Africa.
- Particular emphasis will be given to HIV-infected individuals.
- The study will achieve its aims by implementing shedding and household transmission studies, collecting sequential serum samples, enhancing facility-based (hospitals and clinics) surveillance among patients with mild and severe respiratory illness in well-established population-based surveillance sites where incidence can be calculated, and carrying out healthcare utilisation and serological surveys in selected communities.
- In addition, digital surveillance based on Google searches will be used to complement virological surveillance.
- Nowcasting and short-term forecasting (up to four weeks) will be implemented over the duration of the epidemic

- Prof Cheryl Cohen
  National Institute for Communicable Diseases, South Africa
- Prof Neil Martinson
  University of the Witwatersrand, South Africa
cards.name: Characterization of SARS-CoV-2 transmission dynamics, clinical features and disease impact in South Africa, a setting with high HIV prevalence

cards.desc:
Title: Hepatitis B Viral (Hbv) Infection

PI: Cynthia Finhaber

NB: Ian indicated that this data is nested in the Themba Lethu dataset. We will archive this card if this is confirmed.

‌

The main hypothesis of the study was to determine the prevalence of occult HBV infection in HIV-positive people in South Africa using sensitive molecular techniques for detecting HBV DNA in serum .

The study does not provide information about the age of the participants. However, it reports that 502 patients attending an urban hospital were screened for HBV using serological testing for HBsAg, core antibody (anti-HBc), and surface antibody (anti-HBs). DNA was analyzed using real-time quantitative PCR to determine the HBV viral load.

‌

doi: 10.1016/j.ijid.2008.08.018

[Occult hepatitis B virus infection in patients with isolated core antibody and HIV co-infection in an urban clinic in Johannesburg, South Africa - ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971208015415 "‌")

‌

The study, titled "A Phase IIb, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of the Safety and Immunogenicity of Ad26.Mos4.HIV in HIV-1-Negative Adults in South Africa," was published in the journal AIDS in 2008. The study was conducted by researchers from the University of KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa and the University of California, San Francisco.

The study enrolled 398 HIV-1-negative adults in South Africa. Participants were randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments:

Ad26.Mos4.HIV, a vaccine that is designed to elicit a strong immune response against HIV-1
Placebo
The primary outcome of the study was the safety of Ad26.Mos4.HIV. The study found that Ad26.Mos4.HIV was safe and well-tolerated. The most common side effects were mild and included injection site pain, fever, and fatigue.

The secondary outcome of the study was the immunogenicity of Ad26.Mos4.HIV. The study found that Ad26.Mos4.HIV elicited a strong immune response against HIV-1. The vaccine was able to generate antibodies that could neutralize HIV-1.

The study did not provide any data on how to access the data. However, the study was funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the NIH has a policy of making data from NIH-funded studies available to the public. Therefore, it is likely that the data from this study is available to the public.

cards.desc:
## Abstract

**Background:** High BMI has been shown to be protective against tuberculosis (TB) among HIV-uninfected individuals, as well as against disease progression and mortality among those with HIV. We examined the effect of BMI on all-cause mortality and TB incidence among a cohort of HIV-infected adults in Soweto, South Africa.

**Methods:** A clinical cohort of 3456 HIV-infected adults from South Africa was prospectively followed from 2003 to 2008 with regular monitoring. The primary exposure was BMI and the outcomes of interest were all-cause mortality and a newly diagnosed episode of TB. Cox proportional hazard models assessed associations with risk of mortality or incident TB.

**Results:** Incidence rates of mortality were 10.4/100 person-years for baseline BMI of 18.5 or less, 3.6/100 person-years for baseline BMI 18.6-25, 1.7/100 person-years for baseline BMI 25.1-30, and 1.6/100 person-years for baseline BMI more than 30. Compared to those with normal BMI, overweight and obese participants had a significantly reduced risk of mortality [adjusted hazard ratio 0.59 (95% confidence interval, CI 0.40-0.87) and 0.48 (95% CI 0.29-0.80), respectively]. Incidence rates of TB by baseline BMI were 7.3/100 person-years for underweight, 6.0/100 person-years for normal, 3.2/100 person-years for overweight, and 1.9/100 person-years for obese. Compared to those with normal BMI, those with overweight and obese BMI were at a significantly reduced risk of developing TB [adjusted hazard ratio 0.56 (95% CI 0.38-0.83) and 0.33 (95% CI 0.19-0.55), respectively].

**Conclusion:** HIV-infected individuals with obese and overweight BMI have a significantly reduced risk of both mortality and TB, after adjusting for HAART use and CD4 cell count.

[https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/?term=20505496%2C21076276%2C19525621%2C19564725&format=abstract](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/?term=20505496%2C21076276%2C19525621%2C19564725&format=abstract "smartCard-inline")

cards.desc:
1. **Purpose and Establishment**: The Themba Lethu Clinical Cohort was set up to facilitate large patient-level analyses from a single HIV treatment site. Its primary goal is to evaluate National Treatment Guidelines in South Africa and address questions of national and international policy relevance. It integrates economic and epidemiological perspectives into HIV research​​​​.
2. **Location and Impact**: The cohort is based at the Helen Joseph Hospital in Johannesburg. It has significantly contributed to understanding the effectiveness of HIV treatment rollout. This contribution is not only local but also extends to broader regional and national evaluations, particularly through collaborations with the International Epidemiologic Database to Evaluate AIDS (IeDEA)​​.
3. **Patient Demographics and Results**: Over time, the Themba Lethu Clinical Cohort has grown significantly. It started with less than 2,000 patients in 2004/2005 and expanded to more than 9,000 patients. The cohort, at one point, included over 13,000 patients, demonstrating positive outcomes in terms of mortality, lost to follow-up (LTF), viral suppression, and other factors over the years​​.

Apply for relevant studies from this network

cards.desc:
VOICE trial and some PMTCT data

The VOICE PMTCT trial was a clinical research study led by Dr. Sharon Hillier that aimed to evaluate different methods of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in sub-Saharan Africa. PMTCT stands for "Prevention of Mother-To-Child Transmission" of HIV.

The trial was conducted between 2009 and 2012 and enrolled 5,029 HIV-negative women from South Africa, Uganda, and Zimbabwe who were at high risk of acquiring HIV. The participants were randomly assigned to one of five study groups: three groups received different HIV prevention methods (daily oral tablets of either tenofovir, Truvada, or tenofovir plus emtricitabine), one group received a placebo pill, and one group received a vaginal gel containing tenofovir.

The primary objective of the trial was to determine the safety and efficacy of these methods in preventing HIV transmission from mother to child during breastfeeding. However, the trial results showed that none of the methods tested were effective in reducing HIV transmission rates.

Despite these disappointing results, the VOICE PMTCT trial provided valuable insights into the challenges of implementing effective HIV prevention strategies in resource-limited settings. Dr. Hillier and her team continue to conduct important research on HIV prevention and treatment, including ongoing studies of long-acting antiretroviral drugs and novel strategies for preventing HIV transmission.

‌

NB: Thes requires HREC approval for secondary analysis. This request applies to VOICE, HOPE and ASPIRE

cards.desc:
Liz Montgomery expressed interest in sharing these data.

Here is a summary of the study "Microbicide Ring Acceptability":

The study was conducted to evaluate the acceptability and use of a vaginal microbicide ring for HIV prevention in sub-Saharan Africa. The microbicide ring is a novel method of HIV prevention that involves the use of a ring inserted into the vagina that slowly releases an antiretroviral drug to prevent HIV infection.

The study found that the ring was generally well accepted among women in sub-Saharan Africa. The participants reported that they were comfortable using the ring and that it did not interfere with their daily activities or sexual intercourse. The ring was also found to be easy to insert and remove.

However, some participants reported concerns about potential side effects and the effectiveness of the ring in preventing HIV. There were also concerns about the ring being noticeable to sexual partners.

Overall, the study concluded that while the vaginal microbicide ring is a promising tool for HIV prevention in sub-Saharan Africa, further research is needed to address the concerns raised by the participants. This includes providing more information about the safety and effectiveness of the ring, as well as strategies to ensure that the ring is used consistently and correctly.

Please note that this is a general summary and for more detailed information, you should refer to the full study.

Dr Kartik Venkatesh [kartik.venkatesh@osumc.edu](mailto:kartik.venkatesh@osumc.edu "‌")

cards.desc:
Study title: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 Infection Among Healthcare Workers in South Africa: A Longitudinal Cohort Study

‌

This study investigated severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infections in a cohort of 396 healthcare workers (HCWs) from 5 departments at Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital, South Africa from April to September 2020. The study found that overall, 34.6% of HCWs had polymerase chain reaction–confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection (132.1 [95% confidence interval, 111.8–156.2] infections per 1000 person-months); an additional 27 infections were identified by serology. HCWs in the internal medicine department had the highest rate of infection (61.7%). Among polymerase chain reaction–confirmed cases, 10.4% remained asymptomatic, 30.4% were presymptomatic, and 59.3% were symptomatic. The study concluded that understanding HCWs’ SARS-CoV-2 exposure and risk of infection is critical for characterizing virus transmission patterns, risk factors for infection, and to inform the effectiveness of infection prevention and control practices.

[Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 Infection Among Healthcare Workers in South Africa: A Longitudinal Cohort Study - PMC (nih.gov)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8135922/ "‌")

Study title: An Evaluation of Strategies to Accelerate Entry-into-care following HIV Diagnosis
among Adults in Gauteng and Limpopo Provinces, South Africa

N=1250

‌

Dear all,

‌

I wanted to share a summary of our recent productive meeting with Salome Charalambous and Chris Hoffman, where we discussed the Heat Center project. The project aims to understand the relationship between climate data (primarily temperature) and health data in Johannesburg and Abhijan. The project requires clinical trial and cohort data sets from 2000-2022 with geolocation information, demographic information, lab data, and blood samples.

‌

During the meeting, we covered the following topics:

1. The Heat Center project: I introduced the project, outlining its main aims and the data needed.
2. Finding relevant studies: Salome and I discussed potential studies that might contribute to the project, including TB trials (especially Rifaquin), COVID trials, and HIV trials.
3. Data sharing and governance: We also talked about the process of obtaining and sharing the data, such as legal agreements and privacy assurances.

‌

The way forward for this project is as follows:

1. Identify studies with relevant data: Salome and I will work together to find suitable databases before proceeding further with the project.
2. Data sharing process: We will engage with our legal teams and data holders to establish data transfer or data sharing agreements.
3. Address potential issues: The team will discuss any concerns, such as capturing addresses electronically, with the data sharing committee before making any decisions.

‌

As an action item, I will send the presentation to Salome for the upcoming data governance meeting. In the meantime, Salome will consult with her team to determine which databases would be most suitable for the project. An intern will also be involved in moving things forward.

‌

Thank you all for your commitment to this project. We look forward to working together to achieve our goals and will keep you updated on our progress.

Best regards,

cards.desc:
Study title: Novel TB Prevention Regimens for HIV-Infected Adults

Follow up with Richard E. Chaisson, MD Professor of Medicine, Epidemiology, and International Health Director, Johns Hopkins Center for Tuberculosis Research Principal Investigator, Johns Hopkins Center for AIDS Research

N=1148

Background Treatment of latent tuberculosis in patients infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is efficacious, but few patients around the world receive such treatment. We evaluated three new regimens for latent tuberculosis that may be more potent and durable than standard isoniazid treatment. Methods We randomly assigned South African adults with HIV infection and a positive tuberculin skin test who were not taking antiretroviral therapy to receive rifapentine (900 mg) plus isoniazid (900 mg) weekly for 12 weeks, rifampin (600 mg) plus isoniazid (900 mg) twice weekly for 12 weeks, isoniazid (300 mg) daily for up to 6 years (continuous isoniazid), or isoniazid (300 mg) daily for 6 months (control group). The primary end point was tuberculosis-free survival. Results The 1148 patients had a median age of 30 years and a median CD4 cell count of 484 per cubic millimeter. Incidence rates of active tuberculosis or death were 3.1 per 100 person-years in the rifapentine–isoniazid group, 2.9 per 100 person-years in the rifampin–isoniazid group, and 2.7 per 100 person-years in the continuous-isoniazid group, as compared with 3.6 per 100 person-years in the control group (P>0.05 for all comparisons). Serious adverse reactions were more common in the continuousisoniazid group (18.4 per 100 person-years) than in the other treatment groups (8.7 to 15.4 per 100 person-years). Two of 58 isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (3.4%) were found to have multidrug resistance

‌

cards.name: JHB_JHSPH_005_Novel TB Prevention Regimens for HIV-Infected Adults

cards.desc:
Sydney Brenner Institute for Molecular Bioscience

Middle-aged Soweto Cohort (MASC) which includes the men and women who were part of the original AWI-Gen 1 study (2011-2014; n=~2000) and who were followed up again in 2017/2018 as part of a diabetes study (n=~1000).  AWI-Gen 2 was then completed in 2021/2022 on n=1400.

As agreed I think it is probably best to start moving forward with the most recent data and hopefully in time we can start to explore the historical data more (the women from the MASC cohort were the original Bt20 caregivers so we have historical data on them at various time points between 1990 and 2010).  Although all of this data is stored on the Wits servers we have worked closely with a data management company (DataQ) to set up the longitudinal database for two time points so far (2011-2014 and 2017/2018). Obviously this data is de-identified so we will have to link to addresses etc stored on the Wits servers but this should be easily done with IDs.

PI: Dr Shane Norris

‌
